content.description:
A relatively consistent adventure for a 5.9 leader. Bring runners to avoid the rope drag. If there is a crux it would most likely be at the very top just before the anchors. Unless you have an 80m rope it is probably best to belay your second from the rings at the top and move over to the anchor on your right to rapel to the ledge below, where you can walk off.

Climbs up the faces near the left arette, to the left of Mr. T's Wild Ride.
Many Bolts, Rings

Start up the face in the alcove, stemming and finding holds in the seams. Move up and left following the bolts to a large ledge. Walk around the tree to access the rest of the climb. The holds become thinner until finally the crux is pulling onto the slab. Resist the temptation to grab the anchor before becoming established on the slab.

About 3/4 of the way down the cliff from the path leading in and out. The start of the climb is located at a natural low spot in the path along the cliff base, and is in a very shallow alcove.
bolts to rings

Climb the ramp in the dihedral. Lots of decent holds lead to a crux just before the anchor. Some foot magic can make this go smoothly.

After walking around the boulders from the Phat Tuesday area, head up a hill and you will find the Baiting Bambi dihedral on your left.
5 Bolts, Rings

Originally this route starts from the ledge above the Whiskey and a Headlamp ledge, but a longer variation can include the Whiskey and a Headlamp slab as a link up. The first few bolts off the ledge are bouldery and fun, leading to some slab climbing which is best ended at the rings for Whiskey and a Headlamp.

Starts from the ledge above the Whiskey and a Headlamp ledge immediately to the right of the same routes dihedral.
Bolts, rings

Start at the base of the juggy slab with a tree growing a third of the way up. Head up using large holds to the crux where a couple of cracks provide a change of pace. This climb has become a common first sport lead for locals.

About 5 meters right of Cocksure.
7 bolts to rings

Slabby corner up to slightly overhanging face. Fun moves and well bolted.



Area to the down the path to the right(Facing the cliff) of Totally Industrial

6 Bolts, 2 Rings

Climb the large rails up the face to gain the arete. The crux is just below the second bolt. Shorter climbers may find it difficult to hang a draw on the second bolt without moving through the crux first. The crux can be tenuous and difficult to read, so be aware and plan accordingly.

The far left end of the crag. This is the first sport route on the left side. Rappelling from the rings recommended.
3 bolts to rings

To the right side of the large boulder Twinkle Toes climbs. The start of the climb is a little run out, but very easy 5.2 terrain. Move up to the right leaning crack in the dihedral. Here the protection is good. Follow this dihedral until you can move left onto a ramp that will take you to a set of rings.

To the right of Twinkle Toes.
Standard rack to 1.5”, Rings

Climb the arete. The first bolt can be clipped from the ground from the right side of the arete. The crux is between the third and fourth bolt. Look around and find the best options.

Located in the Hollywood Bowl above She's Got a Dripping Wet Crack. The bolted arete between the two crack climbs.
4 bolts, Rings

Start in the dihedral to the left or Cocksure and head straight up. The crux is at the bottom. This short line can anchor at a tree or at the rings for Cocksure.

This route is located on the far left end of G-spot. Start in the dihedral to the left or Cocksure. Rappelling off the rings or the tree is recommended.
G - takes good gear. There are rings, or a tree to anchor.

Start in the chimney to the left of Twinkle Toe’s using the crack on the left for protection. Head to the ledge and over the bulge past a bolt. Climb up through the flake and into Parade off Whores for the last 3 bolts.

In the chimney to the left of Twinkle Toe’s.
Standard To 2”, Rings

Climb the fun but short overhung face by starting in the crack on the right, and moving left to another crack that leads to the rings. Originally envisioned and Top Roped by Dan Jolivet who named it Harder Is My Safe Word, it was later bolted and climbed by Mick Levin and Rich LaPaix.

The overhung face right of Where the Sun Don't Shine.
3 bolts, rings

Trends right on slab up towards inviting crack at which point traverse right, go up a fantastic layback, and continue to the top.  
  
 Varied climbing. Expect some runouts on easier terrain, and bring some alpine draws! 
  
 You can safely rappel to a ledge and then walk off from there to the bottom.

Climbs the wall across the gully from Phat Tuesday.
Bolts (10).

Start the same as for March of Saints. Continue through the two bolt on the right hand slab rather than join Parade of Whores. The second of the two bolts can be reached from a safe stance by those with longer reach. If you are short try not to fall!

Start in the chimney to the left of Twinkle Toes.
Standard to 2”, Rings

Fun slab climbing leads to a pretty juggy finish. The crux is located low at the second to third bolt, but you are well protected. Be sure to bring a few runners, or just deal with the rope drag.

This climbs the slab to the right of a large dihedral with a tree growing about 15 or 20 feet up.
lots of bolts, rings at the anchor

The real crux of this route is the gear. Its small and finicky. There is a very nice cam off the deck that will protect your belayer, after that you are into .5 and under. Climb the dihedral to the roof and follow it left. Move up to a nice juggy rest and take your time finding placements before moving onto the dirty slab to the rings.

Located in the Hollywood Bowl above She's Got a Dripping Wet Crack. The crack on the left side of the arete.
PG, Small stuff to #1 Camalot

climbs.name: Safetry is My Middle Name (No Call Waiting)

content.description:
Orginally climbed by scrambling/bush whacking to the base. The first pitch was added in June of 2018 by Todd Foster and Alec Soucy to provide better access. The first Pitch was given the name No Call Waiting, and the grade 5.9. Both pitches are not very long and can be combined, but the first pitch wanders and the rope will travel through bushes leading to a wee bit-o rope drag.

Pitch 1 - No Call Waiting, 5.9, 40ft, 4 bolts, rings: Stem up to the first bolt. try to clip the second from the low jugs if you can, otherwise reach high and deep to get a jug. Consider extending your next bolt(s) if climbing through, otherwise easy climbing leads to rings at the base of pitch 2.

Pitch 2 - Safetry is my Middle Name, 5.10a, 30ft, 5 bolts, rings: Climb the slightly overhung featured rock, pull onto the slab, and rejoice. 

The route farthest left. From Knowledge Enema move left around the corner, walk 7 feet to a chimney with bolts on the left side.
10 bolts, rings at both anchors

Start as for the rock climb "dripping crack" and dry tool up 4m before stepping left into a groove.  Climb an ice bulge to the ledge and move left to a ring anchor. 

Hike up to the left and then climb a final short ice slab to the top.  This climb is best done early in the day due to the southern aspect. 



Head to "Dripping Crack" at the Spot.

Nuts and cams to #2 and thin screws.

Climb the gentle ramp using the undecrling crack for protection. The crux is at the very end of the route, getting to the Hollywood Bowl ledge. This is the easiest way to reach Hollywood Bowl if you have a trad rack.

The obvious ramp on the right side of the mini amphitheater with Baiting Bambi on the left.
G gear. Standard rack up to #1 Camalot

really fun climbing up the tall crack system in the gully between bye bye beep and teenage burnout. wide crack to guard the top out.



Between teenage burnout and to beep or not to beep.

G, Ring Anchors, rack up to #4

The crux is at the very start of the route. Pull over the edge of the roof and onto the face, balance your way up to the rings. This climb is good, and a new glue in at the base of the climb makes it much less scary to start!

to the right and up several meters from Bye Bye Beep. Look for the arete to the right of a dihedral. You'll have to scramble up to the base of the climb.
5 bolts to rings

This balancy steep slab requires an intricate sequence of movement on very thin holds to reach a jug where things get easier before making it to the rings. The crux move involves using a tiny side pull that may not last!

This climb starts on a ledge and is not easy to see from the ground. The ledge can be accessed by climbing the first 3 bolts of Parade of Whores, or by scrambling up the ramp immediately to the left.
6 bolts to rings

Starts on the arete directly under the large roof feature. Balance through the slab start to reach the roof. Pulling the roof is the crux, but be prepared for a serious absence of holds above the large horizontal seam.

Where the path into the crag meets the cliff.
bolts to rings

Start on the slab as for Mr. T's Wild Ride using the bolts for protection to get to the slightly overhung crack above. Alternatively climb the dirty poorly protected bush filled crack left of the slab to avoid clipping those silly bolts. Once you arrive at the crack the real fun begins! It's short, but worth it. the cracks get thinner as you move to the anchor, with the last moves being the crux.

The crack above the slab of  Mr. T's Wild Ride, to the right of  Flake'n on the Tard 
5 bolts, G gear, Bring cams between 0.5 and 3 Camalot (a #4 is handy but not necessary), Rings

A short slab climb located on a detached boulder. Use good feet to move through the crux at the start and onto better holds.

About 5m right and up from Parade of Whores.
3 bolts to rings

Start on the face, to the right of the obvious pocket. The first crux is right off of the ground, making it advisable to stick clip the high first bolt. Move through the pocket to the sloppy arete. Follow the arete into the corner (crux), and over the bulge to the rings.

The slab/face right of Baiting Bambi that moves through the obvious pocket to reach the first bolt.
5 bolts, Rings

Climb the bolted slabby arrete to the right of Phat Tuesday. When you reach a ledge head to the crack in the dihedral to climb over a bulge where more bolted slab will take you to the right and to an anchor. A 60m rope will just reach the ground for a rappel.

The arrete to the right of Phat Tuesday.
bolts, standard rack to 1.5", rings

Scramble up some scrufty leges towards a small roof that you can see from the ground, with a shallow right-facing corner/dihedral above it.

It says it is mixed but you can just sport climb it... Anchor at the top

The Spot is primarily sport climbing, although there are a few traditional routes. The cliff has several tiers that can be reached by climbing or by hiking to the NW end of the cliff and doing some significant bush whacking and path finding.

The climbs at The Spot (formerly known as the G Spot) tend to be of moderate or easy difficulty making it a relatively good place to begin lead climbing in NS.

That said, if you're new, the local ethic is to leave no trace. This includes not spray painting the rocks or tossing cigarette butts around. You'd think that would be obvious, but here we are.
